title: Budweiser Brewer Anheuser-Busch Toasts Refreshingly Strong Hong Kong Debut
text:
Text size

Investors toasted a refreshingly strong IPO debut for Anheuser-Busch’s Asian business as it climbed on its Hong Kong opening.

Budweiser APAC shares rose 4.4%, shrugging off concerns over political unrest in the region and a weak IPO climate so far this year.

The back story.

In July the company had canceled plans for what would have been the largest IPO of the year, opting against the $9.8 billion listing of its Asian business in Hong Kong, citing “prevailing market conditions.”

Trade tensions between the U.S. and China had hit markets and Hong Kong itself has been plagued with protests.

A number of Hong Kong listings have been shelved this year due to the political unrest, including Alibaba’s IPO, which was would have been for up to $15 billion.

Less than a week later, Anheuser-Busch InBev agreed to sell its Australian assets to Japanese brewer Asahi Group Holdings for $11.3 billion, shrinking its debt pile.

Earlier this month the Budweiser, Beck’s and Stella Artois brewer revived plans to list its Asian unit in Hong Kong with a slimmed down IPO.

What’s new.

The Belgian brewer’s Asian business - Budweiser APAC - climbed 4.4% on its Hong Kong trading debut on Monday.

Shares closed at HK$28.20 after opening at HK$27.20 - the bottom of its expected range, giving the business a market cap of roughly $47 billion.

The IPO raised $5 billion, making it the second largest IPO of the year behind Uber, which raised $8.1 billion from its New York listing in May.

Moving forward.

Budweiser APAC performed strongly on its debut and even more impressively when put in the context of recent major IPOs.

Indoor cycling company Peloton fell 11% on its debut last week, while Uber had dropped 7% on its opening day.

The slimmed down, more realistically priced IPO has gone down well with investors, who could be toasting further gains in the future.

Shares in the company’s main Belgian listing have jumped 50% so far in 2019 and the Hong Kong listing could be set to unlock greater shareholder value.
description: Investors toasted a refreshingly strong IPO debut as Anheuser-Busch’s Asian business climbed on its Hong Kong opening.
